list.title: Question 1
list.content: Which of the following statements doesnot\textbf{not}notconform to the definition of a mole?A.\hspace{1em}1 mole is the number of H2_{2}2​O molecules in 18.02 g of H2_{2}2​OB.\hspace{1em}1 mole of Fe has a mass equal to the relative atomic mass of Fe in gramsC.\hspace{1em}1 mole of any substance contains 6.02×\times×1023^{23}23particlesD.\hspace{1em}1 mole is the number of H2_{2}2​molecules in 1.01 g ofHX2\ce{H2}HX2​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:1 mole is the number ofHX2\ce{H_{2}}HX2​molecules in 2.02 g ofHX2\ce{H_{2}}HX2​. Choices A, B, and C all conform to the definition of a mole.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which compound has the largest molar mass?A.\hspace{1em}FeSOX4\ce{FeSO4}FeSOX4​B.\hspace{1em}KX2CrX2OX7\ce{K2Cr2O7}KX2​CrX2​OX7​C.\hspace{1em}KMnOX4\ce{KMnO4}KMnOX4​D.\hspace{1em}(NHX4)X3POX4\ce{(NH4)3PO4}(NHX4​)X3​POX4​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:M(KX2CrX2OX7\ce{K2Cr2O7}KX2​CrX2​OX7​) = (2)( 39.10) + (2)( 52) + (7)(16) =294.2gmol−1294.2\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}294.2gmol−1The other compounds have lower molar masses compared toKX2CrX2OX7\ce{K2Cr2O7}KX2​CrX2​OX7​.FeSOX4\ce{FeSO4}FeSOX4​(151.9gmol−1151.9\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}151.9gmol−1),KMnOX4\ce{KMnO4}KMnOX4​(158gmol−1158\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}158gmol−1),(NHX4)X3POX4\ce{(NH4)3PO4}(NHX4​)X3​POX4​(149.1gmol−1149.1\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}149.1gmol−1)

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Which of the following statements is true?A.\hspace{1em}The empirical formula shows only the type of each atom in a molecule.B.\hspace{1em}The molecular formula is always the same as the empirical formula.C.\hspace{1em}Organic molecules often have different empirical and molecular formulas.D.\hspace{1em}The empirical formula is always greater than the molecular formula.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound. The empirical formula can sometimes be the same as the molecular formula. Choices A, B, and D are all false statements.

list.title: Question 4
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The empirical molar mass is approximately 14, so56.12414\dfrac{56.124}{14}1456.124​= 4.Therefore,the molecular formula is4×(CHX2)4\times \ce{(CH2)}4×(CHX2​), orCX4HX8\ce{C4H8}CX4​HX8​.Choice C does not have this formula.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Calculate the number of moles in20.520.520.5grams of sodium phosphate (NaX3POX4\ce{Na3PO4}NaX3​POX4​).A.\hspace{1em}0.125 molB.\hspace{1em}1.25 molC.\hspace{1em}12.5 molD.\hspace{1em}125 mol
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The molar mass of sodium phosphate is 163.94 g mol−1^{-1}−1. Divide the mass (20.5 g) of sodium phosphate by the molar mass to calculate the number of moles of the compound. The rest of the choices are incorrect.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which of the following substances would have the lowest mass?A.\hspace{1em}2.50 molesHX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​OB.\hspace{1em}2.50 molesCHX4\ce{CH4}CHX4​C.\hspace{1em}2.00 molesSOX2\ce{SO2}SOX2​D.\hspace{1em}2.00 molesCOX2\ce{CO2}COX2​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:m(CHX4)=n×M=(2.50mol)(16.05gmol−1)=40.1g\ce{m(CH_4)} = n \times M = (2.50\,\text{mol})(16.05\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 40.1\,\text{g}m(CHX4​)=n×M=(2.50mol)(16.05gmol−1)=40.1gThe other compounds would have a greater mass.m(HX2O)=(2.50mol)(18.02gmol−1)=45.05g\ce{m(H2O)} = (2.50\,\text{mol})(18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 45.05\,\text{g}m(HX2​O)=(2.50mol)(18.02gmol−1)=45.05gm(SOX2)=(2.00moles)(64.07gmol−1)=128.14g\ce{m(SO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(64.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 128.14\,\text{g}m(SOX2​)=(2.00moles)(64.07gmol−1)=128.14gm(COX2)=(2.00moles)(44.01gmol−1)=88.02g\ce{m(CO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =88.02\,\text{g}m(COX2​)=(2.00moles)(44.01gmol−1)=88.02g

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Refer to the following chemical equation:2NOX2(g)→NX2OX4(g)\ce{2NO2 (g) -> N2O4 (g)}2NOX2​(g)​NX2​OX4​(g)At the same temperature and pressure,25.0cm325.0\,\text{cm}^325.0cm3of nitrogen dioxide (NOX2\ce{NO2}NOX2​) gas is completely converted to dinitrogen tetroxide (NX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​) gas. What will be the volume ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​produced?A.10.0cm3\hspace{1em} 10.0\,\text{cm}^310.0cm3B.12.5cm3\hspace{1em} 12.5\,\text{cm}^312.5cm3C.25.0cm3\hspace{1em} 25.0\,\text{cm}^325.0cm3D.50.0cm3\hspace{1em} 50.0\,\text{cm}^350.0cm3
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Based on the balanced chemical equation, the number of moles ofNOX2\ce{NO2}NOX2​is twice that ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​. Avogadro's law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas present(252=12.5)\left(\dfrac{25}{2} = 12.5\right)(225​=12.5).

list.title: Question 8
list.content: How many molecules are there in 4.80 mol of glucose?A.\hspace{1em}2.89×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesB.\hspace{1em}2.50×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesC.\hspace{1em}3.50×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesD.\hspace{1em}2.59×\times×1024^{24}24molecules
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Use Avogadro's number to interconvert the number of molecules to the amount of molecules in moles:N=n×NAN = n \times N_{A}N=n×NA​N=4.80mol×6.02×1023molecules1molN = 4.80\,\textrm{mol} \times \dfrac{6.02 \times 10^{23}\,\textrm{molecules}}{1\,\textrm{mol}}N=4.80mol×1mol6.02×1023molecules​= 2.89×\times×1024molecules^{24}\,\text{molecules}24molecules

Therefore, its empirical formula is C5_{5}5​H6_{6}6​O✓\checkmark✓(ratio C : H : O = 5 : 6 : 1)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Divide by the highest common factor (2) to determine the simplest whole number ratio

list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:First, we need to find moles ofMg(OH)X2\ce{Mg(OH)2}Mg(OH)X2​in 5.83 g:nMg(OH)X2=mMn_\ce{Mg(OH)2} = \dfrac{m}{M}nMg(OH)X2​​=Mm​nMg(OH)X2=5.83g58.3g mol−1=0.100moln_\ce{Mg(OH)2}= \dfrac{5.83\text{\ g}}{58.3\text{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 0.100\text{\ mol}nMg(OH)X2​​=58.3g mol−15.83g​=0.100molTo find the total number of ions in 0.100 moles ofMg(OH)X2,\ce{Mg(OH)2},Mg(OH)X2​,we need to consider the formula ofMg(OH)X2\ce{Mg(OH)2}Mg(OH)X2​and then calculate the number of ions it dissociates into when dissolved in water. The formula of magnesium hydroxide,Mg(OH)X2,\ce{Mg(OH)2},Mg(OH)X2​,suggests that each formula unit contains one magnesium ion,MgX2+,\ce{Mg^2+},MgX2+,and two hydroxide ions,OHX−.\ce{OH-}.OHX−.SinceMg(OH)X2\ce{Mg(OH)2}Mg(OH)X2​dissociates into one magnesium ion and two hydroxide ions per formula unit, we have 0.100 moles of magnesiumMgX2+\ce{Mg^2+}MgX2+ions and 0.200 moles of hydroxideOHX−\ce{OH-}OHX−ions.To find the total number of ions, we need to multiply these quantities by Avogadro's number:N=nNAN = n N_AN=nNA​NMgX2+=(0.100mol)(6.0×1023mol−1)=0.60×1023ionsMgX2+N_\ce{Mg^2+} = (0.100\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 0.60\times 10^{23}\text{\ ions }\ce{Mg^2+}NMgX2+​=(0.100mol)(6.0×1023mol−1)=0.60×1023ionsMgX2+NOHX−=(0.200mol)(6.0×1023mol−1)=1.2×1023ionsOHX−N_\ce{OH-} = (0.200\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 1.2\times 10^{23}\ \ce{ions OH-}NOHX−​=(0.200mol)(6.0×1023mol−1)=1.2×1023ionsOHX−Adding the two numbers together gives us the answer1.8×10231.8\times 10^{23}1.8×1023which is option B.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Which statement aboutNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​isincorrect?A.\hspace{1em}Its empirical formula isNOX2.\ce{NO2}.NOX2​.B.\hspace{1em}Its percentage composition is 30.45% nitrogen.C.\hspace{1em}Its percentage composition is 53.32% oxygen.D.\hspace{1em}Its molar mass is92.02g mol−1.92.02\,\text{g mol}^{-1}.92.02g mol−1.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms of each element present in that compound.NX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​has two nitrogen atoms for every four oxygen atoms, the simplest ratio is1:2,1:2,1:2,and the empirical formula isNOX2.\ce{NO2}.NOX2​.The molar mass ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​can be determined by adding the masses of each atom.M=2(14.01)+4(16.00)=92.02g mol−1M = 2(14.01) + 4(16.00) = 92.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}M=2(14.01)+4(16.00)=92.02g mol−1The percentage composition must be calculated by assuming one mole of the substance.  For nitrogen:%N=mNmNOX2×100%=2(14.01g)92.02g×100%=30.45%\%\ce{N} = \dfrac{m_\ce{N}}{m_{\ce{NO2}}} \times 100\% = \dfrac{2(14.01 \textrm{\ g})}{92.02 \textrm{\ g}} \times 100\%  = 30.45\%%N=mNOX2​​mN​​×100%=92.02g2(14.01g)​×100%=30.45%Since there are only two elements, the mass percent of oxygen is100−%N=69.55%.100 - \%\ce{N} = 69.55 \%.100−%N=69.55%.This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to understand the difference between empirical and molecular formulae and should also be able to calculate the percentage composition.

Use the molar mass of each element.✓\checkmark✓n=mM=46.56g12.01gmol−1n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{46.56\,\text{g}}{12.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}n=Mm​=12.01gmol−146.56g​=3.88mol3.88\,\text{mol}3.88molCn=mM=6.85g1.01gmol−1n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.85\,\text{g}}{1.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}n=Mm​=1.01gmol−16.85g​=6.78mol6.78\,\text{mol}6.78molHn=mM=15.5g16.00gmol−1n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{15.5\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}n=Mm​=16.00gmol−115.5g​=0.97mol0.97\,\text{mol}0.97molOn=mM=31.08g32.07gmol−1n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{31.08\,\text{g}}{32.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}n=Mm​=32.07gmol−131.08g​=0.97mol0.97\,\text{mol}0.97molSDivide all the number of moles by the smallest mole value calculated in the previous step.The number of moles of C, H, O, and S will be divided by 0.97.✓\checkmark✓For C:3.880.97\dfrac{3.88}{0.97}0.973.88​=4For H:6.780.97\dfrac{6.78}{0.97}0.976.78​=6.99For O:0.970.97\dfrac{0.97}{0.97}0.970.97​=1For S:0.970.97\dfrac{0.97}{0.97}0.970.97​=1Round your answers to the nearest whole number. The numbers rounded off will be the subscripts of each element in the empirical formula. The empirical formula of lipoic acid isC4_{4}4​H7_{7}7​OS.✓\checkmark✓M(CX4HX7OS)=(4)(12.01)+(7)(1.01)+16.00+32.07=M(\ce{C4H7OS}) = (4)(12.01) + (7)(1.01) + 16.00 + 32.07 =M(CX4​HX7​OS)=(4)(12.01)+(7)(1.01)+16.00+32.07=103.18gmol−1103.18\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}103.18gmol−1✓\checkmark✓206.44103.18\dfrac{206.44}{103.18}103.18206.44​= 2✓\checkmark✓The molecular formula of lipoic acid isCX8HX14OX2SX2\ce{C8H14O2S2}CX8​HX14​OX2​SX2​✓\checkmark✓ALLOWerrorcarriedforwardfromincorrectempiricalformulacalculationin(a)\textit{ALLOW error carried forward from incorrect empirical formula calculation in }\text{(a)}ALLOW error carried forward from incorrect empirical formula calculation in(a)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​To determine the molecular formula, first divide the molar mass of the compound by the molar mass of the empirical formula. Second, multiply the empirical formula by the scaling factor 2 which doubles the number of atoms of each element for the molecular formula.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: The elemental composition of compoundB\textbf{B}Bis given in the table.\enskipElement\enskipAbundance/%mass\enskip \textbf{Abundance} \mathbf{\ /\ \% mass}\enskipAbundance/%massC\ce{C}C75H\ce{H}H25What is the empirical formula of compoundB\textbf{B}B?Atomic masses (amu)C=12,H=1\ce{C} = 12, \ce{H} = 1C=12,H=1A.CX3H\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H}CX3​HB.CH\hspace{1em}\ce{CH}CHC.CX3HX2\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H2}CX3​HX2​D.CHX4\hspace{1em}\ce{CH4}CHX4​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To determine the empirical formula, assume a 100 g sample of the compound. This would contain 75 g of carbon and 25 g of hydrogen. Converting to moles givesnC=75g C12g mol−1=6.25moln_{\ce{C}} = \dfrac{75 \textrm{\ g C}}{12 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 6.25 \textrm{\ mol}nC​=12g mol−175g C​=6.25molnH=25g H1g mol−1=25moln_{\ce{H}} = \dfrac{25 \textrm{\ g H}}{1 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 25 \textrm{\ mol}nH​=1g mol−125g H​=25molThe simplest whole number ratio is therefore6.25:25,6.25 : 25,6.25:25,which simplifies to1:4.1 : 4.1:4.This means that for every one atom of carbon there are four atoms of hydrogen, so the empirical formula isCHX4\ce{CH4}CHX4​.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Complete combustion of50cm350\text{\ cm}^350cm3of a hydrocarbon vapour produces350cm3350\text{\ cm}^3350cm3of carbon dioxide at the same temperature and pressure. Which is a possible molecular formula of the hydrocarbon?A.CX8HX18\hspace{1em}\ce{C8H18}CX8​HX18​B.CX7HX16\hspace{1em}\ce{C7H16}CX7​HX16​C.CX6HX14\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H14}CX6​HX14​D.CX5HX12\hspace{1em}\ce{C5H12}CX5​HX12​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To determine the molecular formula of the alkane, we start by understanding the general reaction for the complete combustion of a hydrocarbon:CXxHXy+(x+y4)OX2→xCOX2+(y2)HX2O\ce{C_xH_y + \left(\dfrac{x+y}{4}\right) O2 -> x CO2 + \left(\dfrac{y}{2}\right) H2O}CXx​HXy​​+(4x+y​)OX2​​xCOX2​+(2y​)HX2​OVolume of hydrocarbon vapour=50cm3= 50\text{\ cm}^3=50cm3Volume of carbon dioxide produced=350cm3= 350\text{\ cm}^3=350cm3The volumes of gases are proportional to the number of moles (at constant temperature and pressure). Therefore, we can infer the number of moles directly from the volumes given.From the reaction stoichiometry, we see that 1 mole of hydrocarbon(CXxHXy)(\ce{C_xH_y})(CXx​HXy​​)producesxxxmoles ofCOX2.\ce{CO2}.COX2​.Since we start with50cm350\text{\ cm}^350cm3of hydrocarbon and produce350cm3350\text{\ cm}^3350cm3ofCOX2:\ce{CO2}:COX2​:x1=350cm350cm3;x=7\dfrac{x}{1} = \dfrac{350\text{\ cm}^3}{50\text{\ cm}^3};\quad  x = 71x​=50cm3350cm3​;x=7As an alkane, the general formula isCXnHX2n+2.\ce{C_nH_{2n+2}}.CXn​HX2n+2​​.The alkane here isCX7HX16.\ce{C7H16}.CX7​HX16​.

list.title: Question 20
list.content: If 1.20 g of magnesium metal reacts with excess hydrobromic acid, what volume of hydrogen gas is evolved at STP, given the molar volume at STP is 22.4 dm3^33?A.\hspace{1em}0.224 dm3^33B.\hspace{1em}2.24 dm3^33C.\hspace{1em}1.12 dm3^33D.\hspace{1em}4.48 dm3^33
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:V=n×Vm=1.20g24g mol−1×22.4dm3mol−1=1.12dm3V = n \times V_m= \dfrac{1.20\,\text{g}}{24\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}\times 22.4\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 1.12\,\text{dm}^3V=n×Vm​=24g mol−11.20g​×22.4dm3mol−1=1.12dm3

list.title: Question 21
list.content: 36.0 cm3^33of a 1.00 mol dm−3^{-3}−3solution of copper (II) nitrate reacts with 0.540 g of aluminum metal.How many moles of copper metal would be produced in the following reaction?3Cu(NOX3)X2+2Al→2Al(NOX3)X3+3Cu\ce{3 Cu(NO3)2 + 2 Al -> 2 Al(NO3)3 + 3 Cu}3Cu(NOX3​)X2​+2Al​2Al(NOX3​)X3​+3CuA.\hspace{1em}0.0360 molesB.\hspace{1em}0.0300 molesC.\hspace{1em}0.0200 molesD.\hspace{1em}0.0133 moles
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Find the moles of each reactant:Cu(NOX3)X2\ce{Cu(NO3)2}Cu(NOX3​)X2​:n=C×V=1.00mol dm−3×0.036dm3=0.036molCu(NOX3)X2n = C \times V = 1.00\,\textrm{mol dm}^{-3}\times 0.036\,\text{dm}^3 = 0.036\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}n=C×V=1.00mol dm−3×0.036dm3=0.036molCu(NOX3​)X2​Al\ce{Al}Al:n=mM=0.540g27g mol−1=0.020mol Aln = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{0.540\,\text{g}}{27\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.020\,\text{mol Al}n=Mm​=27g mol−10.540g​=0.020mol AlDetermine the limiting reactant by finding the moles of copper(II) nitrate required to react with the aluminium:0.020mol Al×3molCu(NOX3)X22mol Al=0.030molCu(NOX3)X20.020\,\text{mol Al}\times \dfrac{3\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}}{2\,\text{mol  Al}} = 0.030\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}0.020mol Al×2mol Al3molCu(NOX3​)X2​​=0.030molCu(NOX3​)X2​Because0.036molCu(NOX3)X2>0.030molCu(NOX3)X20.036\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2} > 0.030\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}0.036molCu(NOX3​)X2​>0.030molCu(NOX3​)X2​, Al is the limiting reactant.Therefore, the yield of copper can be deduced:0.020mol Al×3mol Cu2mol Al=0.030mol Cu0.020\,\text{mol Al}\times \dfrac{3\,\text{mol Cu}}{2\,\text{mol Al}} = 0.030\,\text{mol Cu}0.020mol Al×2mol Al3mol Cu​=0.030mol CuThe theoretical yield of copper is 0.030 mol Cu.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: Aluminum hydrogen carbonate will decompose to produce aluminum oxide, carbon dioxide gas, and water according to the following equation:2Al(HCOX3)X3(s)→AlX2OX3(s)+6COX2(g)+3HX2O(l)\ce{2 Al(HCO3)3(s) -> Al2O3(s) + 6 CO2(g) + 3 H_2O(l)}2Al(HCOX3​)X3​(s)​AlX2​OX3​(s)+6COX2​(g)+3HX2​O(l)If 0.300 moles of aluminum hydrogen carbonate(Mr≈210)(M_r \approx 210)(Mr​≈210)decomposes and 10.2 g of aluminum oxide(Mr≈102)(M_r \approx 102)(Mr​≈102)is collected, what is the percent yield?A.67.0%\hspace{1em}67.0\%67.0%B.33.0%\hspace{1em}33.0\%33.0%C.75.0%\hspace{1em}75.0\%75.0%D.133%\hspace{1em}133\%133%
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Determine the theoretical yield ofAlX2OX3\ce{Al2O3}AlX2​OX3​using the mole ratio from the balanced chemical equation:0.300molAl(HCOX3)X3×1molAlX2OX32molAl(HCOX3)X3=0.150molAlX2OX30.300\,\text{mol }\ce{Al(HCO3)3}\times \dfrac{1\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}}{2\,\text{mol }\ce{Al(HCO3)3}} = 0.150\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}0.300molAl(HCOX3​)X3​×2molAl(HCOX3​)X3​1molAlX2​OX3​​=0.150molAlX2​OX3​Determine experimental yield ofAlX2OX3\ce{Al2O3}AlX2​OX3​in moles using the relationshipn=mMn = \dfrac{m}{M}n=Mm​.10.2gAlX2OX3102g mol−1=0.100molAlX2OX3\dfrac{10.2\,\text{g }\ce{Al2O3}}{102\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.100\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}102g mol−110.2gAlX2​OX3​​=0.100molAlX2​OX3​Take the ratio to find the percent yield:0.100mol0.150mol×100%=67%\dfrac{0.100\,\text{mol}}{0.150\,\text{mol}}\times 100\% = 67\%0.150mol0.100mol​×100%=67%

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Which is the correct empirical formula for a compound that is composed of 40% sulfur and 60% oxygen by mass?A.SO\hspace{1em}\ce{SO}SOB.SX2OX3\hspace{1em}\ce{S2O3}SX2​OX3​C.SOX2\hspace{1em}\ce{SO2}SOX2​D.SOX3\hspace{1em}\ce{SO3}SOX3​
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​To determine the empirical formula from a mass % composition, first we assume that the sample is 100 g so that the percent composition can be easily converted to mass:40% sulfur⟶\longrightarrow⟶40 g sulfur60% oxygen⟶\longrightarrow⟶60 g oxygenNext, these masses are converted into moles:40g S×1mol32g=1.25mol S40\text{ g S}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{32\text{ g}} = 1.25\text{ mol S}40g S×32g1mol​=1.25mol S60g O×1mol16g=3.75mol O60\text{ g O}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{16\text{ g}} = 3.75\text{ mol O}60g O×16g1mol​=3.75mol OFrom here, the ratio between the atoms is determined:mol Omol S=3.75mol1.25mol=3\dfrac{\text{mol O}}{\text{mol S}} = \dfrac{3.75\text{ mol}}{1.25\text{ mol}} = 3mol Smol O​=1.25mol3.75mol​=3Therefore, there are 3 atoms of oxygen for every 1 atom of sulfur so the empirical formula isSOX3.\ce{SO3}.SOX3​.

list.content: Which of the following solutions has the greatest quantity of moles of ions in solutions?A.200cm3\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3200cm3of1.0mol dm−3NaCl1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}1.0mol dm−3NaClB.200cm3\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3200cm3of1.0mol dm−3MgClX21.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}1.0mol dm−3MgClX2​C.100cm3\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3100cm3of1.0mol dm−3NaCl1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}1.0mol dm−3NaClD.100cm3\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3100cm3of1.0mol dm−3MgClX21.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}1.0mol dm−3MgClX2​
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​To determine the quantity of moles of ions in solution, each compound must be dissociated to reveal the stoichiometry. Next, the moles of each need to be considered using the equationn=CV.n = CV.n=CV.The greatest quantity of ions will be found in the mixtures with the highest volume, so the100cm3100\text{ cm}^3100cm3answer choices can be eliminated.For NaCl:NaCl→NaX++ClX−\ce{NaCl -> Na+ + Cl-}NaCl​NaX++ClX−n=(200cm3)(1dm31000cm3)(1.0mol dm−3)n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{\ mol dm}^{-3})n=(200cm3)(1000cm31dm3​)(1.0mol dm−3)n=0.20mol NaCln = 0.20\text{ mol NaCl}n=0.20mol NaClThere is a1:11:11:1relationship between the moles of compound and the moles of each ion, therefore there are a total of0.2molNaX++0.2molClX−=0.4mol of ions0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Na+} + 0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = 0.4\text{ mol of ions}0.2molNaX++0.2molClX−=0.4mol of ionsForMgCl2\mathbf{\mathit{MgCl_2}}MgCl2​:MgClX2→MgX2++2ClX−\ce{MgCl2 -> Mg^2+ + 2 Cl-}MgClX2​​MgX2++2ClX−n=(200cm3)(1dm31000cm3)(1.0mol dm−3)n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3})n=(200cm3)(1000cm31dm3​)(1.0mol dm−3)n=0.20molMgClX2n = 0.20\text{ mol }\ce{MgCl2}n=0.20molMgClX2​There is a1:11:11:1relationship between the moles of compound andMgX2+\ce{Mg^2+}MgX2+and a1:21:21:2relationship between the moles of compound andClX−,\ce{Cl-},ClX−,therefore there are a total of0.2molMgX2++0.4molClX−=0.6mol of ions0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Mg^2+} + 0.4\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = \answer{0.6\text{ mol of ions}}0.2molMgX2++0.4molClX−=0.6mol of ions​

list.content: Which of the following solutions will produce a neutral solution when reacted with 0.05 mol of sulfuric acid?A.50.0cm3of1.00mol dm−3NaOH\hspace{1em}50.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text { of }\,  1.00 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \ce{\ NaOH}50.0cm3of1.00mol dm−3NaOHB.100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3NaOH\hspace{1em}100.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text { of }\,  2.00 \textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3} \ce{\ NaOH}100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3NaOHC.100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2\hspace{1em}100.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text{ of }\,  2.00 \textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3}  \ce{\ Ca(OH)2}100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2​D.25.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2\hspace{1em}25.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text{ of }\,  2.00\textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3}  \ce{\ Ca(OH)2}25.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2​

list.title: Question 27
list.content: What is the molecular formula of a compound with an empirical formula ofCHX2O\ce{CH2O}CHX2​Oand a molar mass of180.18g mol−1?180.18 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}?180.18g mol−1?A.CHX2O\hspace{1em}\ce{CH2O}CHX2​OB.CX6HX6OX6\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H6O6}CX6​HX6​OX6​C.CX6HX12OX6\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H12O6}CX6​HX12​OX6​D.CX5HX10OX5\hspace{1em}\ce{C5H10O5}CX5​HX10​OX5​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Students must understand the difference between molecular and empirical formulas.he empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms in a molecule, whereas the molecular formula gives the actual number of atoms present in a molecule. If these two differ, the molecular formula can be deduced from the empirical formula.Empirical formula:CHX2O\ce{CH2O}CHX2​O12.01+2×1.01+16.00=30.03g mol−112.01 + 2\times 1.01 + 16.00 = 30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}12.01+2×1.01+16.00=30.03g mol−1180.18g mol−130.03g mol−1≈6\dfrac{180.18\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}{30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}\approx 630.03g mol−1180.18g mol−1​≈6Molecular formula (six times the empirical formula):CX6HX12OX6\ce{C6H12O6}CX6​HX12​OX6​This question is categorized as medium as students must differentiate between molecular and empirical formulas and deduce the molecular formula with the periodic table and the molar mass given.

list.title: Question 28
list.content: 6.00 g of ethane gas(Mr≈30)(M_r \approx 30)(Mr​≈30)is placed in a flexible container at STP. The conditions are then changed to a new pressure of 200,000 Pa and a new temperature of 546 K.What is the new volume of the container after equilibrating to the new temperature and pressure?The molar volume of a gas at STP is 22.7 dm3^33.A.22.7dm3\hspace{1em}22.7\,\text{dm}^322.7dm3B.2.27dm3\hspace{1em}2.27\,\text{dm}^32.27dm3C.4.54dm3\hspace{1em}4.54\,\text{dm}^34.54dm3D.9.08dm3\hspace{1em}9.08\,\text{dm}^39.08dm3
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​At STP, standard temperature and pressure, the pressure is 100 kPa (100,000 Pa) and the temperature is 0∘^\circ∘C (273 K). A sample of ethane gas is taken from standard conditions and put into new conditions where the pressure is doubled (200000 kPa) and the temperature is doubled (546 K).The amount of ethane is constant through the experiment:nCX2HX6=mM=6.00g30g mol−1=0.200moln_\ce{C2H6} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.00\,\text{g}}{30\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.200\,\text{mol}nCX2​HX6​​=Mm​=30g mol−16.00g​=0.200molUsing the molar volume of a gas at STP, we can deduce the original volume of the gas:V1=nVm=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3V_1 = n V_m = 0.200\,\text{mol}\times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 4.54\,\text{dm}^3V1​=nVm​=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3The final volume of the gas can be determined from the combined gas law:P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​Solving forV2V_2V2​:V2=P1V1T2T1P2V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{T_1P_2}V2​=T1​P2​P1​V1​T2​​;Logically, the pressureP2P_2P2​and the temperatureT2T_2T2​doubled, so the volumeV2V_2V2​remains the same. Mathematically,V2=100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K273K×200000PaV_2 = \dfrac{100000\,\text{Pa}\times 4.54\,\text{dm}^3\times 546\,\text{K}}{273\,\text{K}\times 200000\text{Pa}}V2​=273K×200000Pa100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K​The final volume of ethane is 4.54 dm3^33.

list.title: Question 29
list.content: A sample of9.70g9.70\,\text{g}9.70gof an unknown organic compound composed of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen was burnt with excess oxygen. The combustion produced nitrogen gas,27.5g27.5\,\text{g}27.5gofCOX2\ce{CO2}COX2​and6.57g6.57\,\text{g}6.57gofHX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​O.Calculate the mass of nitrogen produced.[3]Determine the empirical formula of the compound.[2]
list.markScheme: Mass of carbon produced:nC=mM=27.5g44.01gmol−1=0.624moln_C = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{27.5\,\text{g}}{44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.624\,\text{mol}nC​=Mm​=44.01gmol−127.5g​=0.624molmC=(0.624mol)(12.01gmol−1)=m_C = (0.624\,\text{mol})(12.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =mC​=(0.624mol)(12.01gmol−1)=7.49g7.49\,\text{g}7.49g✓\checkmark✓Mass of hydrogen produced:nH=2mM=26.57g18.02gmol−1=0.729moln_H = 2\,\dfrac{m}{M} = 2\,\dfrac{6.57\,\text{g}}{18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.729\,\text{mol}nH​=2Mm​=218.02gmol−16.57g​=0.729molmH=(0.729mol)(1.01gmol−1)=m_H = (0.729\,\text{mol})(1.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =mH​=(0.729mol)(1.01gmol−1)=0.736g0.736\,\text{g}0.736g✓\checkmark✓Mass of nitrogen produced:mN=9.70−(7.49+0.736)=m_N = 9.70 - (7.49 + 0.736) =mN​=9.70−(7.49+0.736)=1.46g1.46\,\text{g}1.46g✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​There is one mole of carbon atoms in every mole of carbon dioxide produced. The number of moles of carbon dioxide are therefore equal to the number of moles of carbon in the original unknown compound.There are two moles of hydrogen atoms in every mole of water produced. The number of  moles of water therefore must be multiplied by 2 to give the number of  moles of H atoms in the original compound.The mass of nitrogen in the organic compound is the same as the mass of nitrogen after combustion due to conservation of mass and can therefore be calculate by subtracting the masses of C and H from the total mass of the unknown organic compound.nN=1.46g14.01gmol−1=n_N = \dfrac{1.46\,\text{g}}{14.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =nN​=14.01gmol−11.46g​=0.104mol0.104\,\text{mol}0.104molDivide the number of moles of each element by the smallest mole value✓\checkmark✓For C:0.6240.104=6\dfrac{0.624}{0.104} = 60.1040.624​=6For H:0.7290.104=7\dfrac{0.729}{0.104} = 70.1040.729​=7For N:0.1040.104=1\dfrac{0.104}{0.104} = 10.1040.104​=1The empirical formula of the compound isCX6HX7N\ce{C6H7N}CX6​HX7​N✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Barium hydroxide and phosphoric acid react according to the following equation:3Ba(OH)X2(aq)+2HX3POX4(aq)→6HX2O(l)+BaX3(POX4)X2(s)\ce{3 Ba(OH)2(aq) + 2 H3PO4(aq) -> 6 H2O(l) + Ba3(PO4)2(s)}3Ba(OH)X2​(aq)+2HX3​POX4​(aq)​6HX2​O(l)+BaX3​(POX4​)X2​(s)What volume of 0.100 mol dm−3^{-3}−3phosphoric acid is required to completely neutralize 50.0 cm3^33of 0.030 mol dm−3^{-3}−3barium hydroxide solution?A.10cm3\hspace{1em}10\,\text{cm}^310cm3B.22.5cm3\hspace{1em}22.5\,\text{cm}^322.5cm3C.15cm3\hspace{1em}15\,\text{cm}^315cm3D.5.0cm3\hspace{1em}5.0\,\text{cm}^35.0cm3
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For neutralization, the moles of the acid must bestoichiometricallyequivalent\textit{stoichiometrically equivalent}stoichiometrically equivalentto the moles of base, that is they must appear in the3:23:23:2ratio given by the balanced chemical equation.First, find the moles of barium hydroxide using the relationshipn=CVn = CVn=CVwherennnis the amount in moles,CCCis the concentration in mol dm−3^{-3}−3andVVVis the volume in dm3^33.nBa(OH)X2=0.030mol dm−3×50.0cm31000cm3dm−3=0.0015moln_\ce{Ba(OH)2} = 0.030\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times \dfrac{50.0\,\text{cm}^3}{1000\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{dm}^{-3}} = 0.0015\,\text{mol}nBa(OH)X2​​=0.030mol dm−3×1000cm3dm−350.0cm3​=0.0015molThe moles of phosphoric acid can be deduced from the mole ratio:nHX3POX4=0.0015molBa(OH)X2×2molHX3POX43molBa(OH)X2=0.0010moln_\ce{H3PO4} = 0.0015\,\text{mol }\ce{Ba(OH)2}\times \dfrac{2\,\text{mol }\ce{H3PO4}}{3\,\text{mol }\ce{Ba(OH)2}} = 0.0010\,\text{mol}nHX3​POX4​​=0.0015molBa(OH)X2​×3molBa(OH)X2​2molHX3​POX4​​=0.0010molThe volume of phosphoric acid can be found with the relathionshipV=nCV = \dfrac{n}{C}V=Cn​, where the volume is converted back the cm3^33to match the answer choices.V=0.0010molHX3POX40.100mol dm−3×1000cm3dm−3=10cm3V = \dfrac{0.0010\,\text{mol }\ce{H3PO4}}{0.100\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}\times 1000\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{dm}^{-3} = 10\,\text{cm}^3V=0.100mol dm−30.0010molHX3​POX4​​×1000cm3dm−3=10cm3The total volume required is10cm310\,\text{cm}^310cm3.

list.title: Question 31
list.content: What is the concentration of sodium ions in a0.356mol dm−30.356 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.356mol dm−3solution of sodium sulfate?A.\hspace{1em}0.356B.\hspace{1em}0.712C.\hspace{1em}0.425D.\hspace{1em}0.850
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sodium sulfate (NaX2SOX4\ce{Na2SO4}NaX2​SOX4​) dissociates in water, releasing two sodium cations.[NaX+]=2×0.356mol dm−3=0.712mol dm−3[\ce{Na+}] = 2\times 0.356\,\text{mol dm}^{-3} = 0.712\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}[NaX+]=2×0.356mol dm−3=0.712mol dm−3This question is categorized as medium difficulty, requiring students to deduce the molecular formula of sodium sulfate and the cation concentration in an aqueous solution.

list.title: Question 32
list.content: A student carried out an experiment to determine the empirical formula of an oxide of manganese.3.60g3.60\,\text{g}3.60gof the metal was heated in the presence of an excess of oxygen. When the metal reacted completely,5.64g5.64\,\text{g}5.64gof metal oxide were formed.Deduce the empirical formula of the oxide.[3]Suggest an experimental technique the student can use to ensure that the manganese has completely reacted.[1]A common impurity in manganese is carbon.  How would this impurity affect the determination of the empirical formula?[2]
list.markScheme: mOX2=5.64−3.60=2.04g✓m_\ce{O2} = 5.64 - 3.60 = 2.04\,\text{g}\ \checkmarkmOX2​​=5.64−3.60=2.04g✓nMn=0.0655n_\ce{Mn} = 0.0655nMn​=0.0655ANDnOX2=0.128✓n_\ce{O2} = 0.128\ \checkmarknOX2​​=0.128✓MnOX2✓\ce{MnO2}\ \checkmarkMnOX2​✓Award full marks for correct final answer.Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The mass of oxygen can be obtained by subtracting the mass of the metal from the mass of the metal oxide.mMnXxOXy−mMn=mOm_\ce{Mn_xO_y} - m_\ce{Mn} = m_\ce{O}mMnXx​OXy​​​−mMn​=mO​5.62g−3.60g=2.02g5.62\,\text{g} - 3.60\,\text{g} = 2.02\,\text{g}5.62g−3.60g=2.02gThe moles for each of the elements can be obtained by applying the formula;n=mMn = \dfrac{m}{M}n=Mm​.nMn=3.60g54.94g mol−1=0.0655moln_\ce{Mn} = \dfrac{3.60\,\text{g}}{54.94\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.0655\,\text{mol}nMn​=54.94g mol−13.60g​=0.0655molnO=2.04g16.00g mol−1=0.128moln_\ce{O} = \dfrac{2.04\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.128\,\text{mol}nO​=16.00g mol−12.04g​=0.128molThe simplest ratio is obtained by dividing the moles of the substance by the smallest value of moles. This is the empirical formula:Mn:0.0655mol0.0655mol=1\dfrac{0.0655\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 10.0655mol0.0655mol​=1O:0.128mol0.0655mol=1.95≈2\dfrac{0.128\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1.95\approx 20.0655mol0.128mol​=1.95≈2The empirical formula isMnOX2\ce{MnO2}MnOX2​.Repeatedly heat and weigh until constant mass is achieved✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The mass of the sample is considered to have reached a constant value when the difference between successive weighings is minimal and falls within an acceptable range of experimental error. This indicates that all of the manganese has reacted with oxygen within practical restrictions.more oxygen will react per unit mass (to formCOX2)✓\ce{CO2})\,\checkmarkCOX2​)✓the ratio of O to Mn will be greater than 2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​If the manganese sample contains carbon as an impurity, it will also react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide. The additional mass of oxygen bonded to carbon would be incorrectly attributed to the formation of the manganese oxide. This would result in an overestimation of the oxygen content in the final product and an artificially high oxygen-to-manganes ratio. Consequently, the empirical formula of the manganese oxide would be determined incorrectly, potentially showing a higher number of oxygen atoms per manganese atom than is accurate (e.g.,MnOX3\ce{MnO3}MnOX3​instead ofMnOX2).\ce{MnO2}).MnOX2​).

list.content: To make a stock solution of aluminum nitrate(Al(NOX3)X3,\ce{(Al(NO3)3},(Al(NOX3​)X3​,Mr=213.00)M_r = 213.00)Mr​=213.00), 10.65 g is dissolved in 150 cm3^33of water.Which calculation below is used to determine the volume, in dm3^33, of the stock solution needed to make 1.0 dm3^33of a 0.050 mol dm−3^{-3}−3aluminum nitrate solution?A.\hspace{1em}10.65×1×0.050213.00×0.150\dfrac{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.050}{213.00 \times 0.150}213.00×0.15010.65×1×0.050​B.\hspace{1em}10.65213.00×0.050×1×0.150\dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.050 \times 1 \times 0.150}213.00×0.050×1×0.15010.65​C.\hspace{1em}0.050×213.00×0.15010.65\dfrac{0.050 \times 213.00 \times 0.150}{  10.65}10.650.050×213.00×0.150​D.\hspace{1em}213.0×0.05010.65×1×0.150\dfrac{213.0 \times 0.050}{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.150}10.65×1×0.150213.0×0.050​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​First, find the concentration of the stock solution,C1C_1C1​.C=nVC = \dfrac{n}{V}C=Vn​n=10.65g213.00g mol−1;V=0.150dm3n = \dfrac{10.65\,\text{g}}{213.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}}; \hspace{0.2in} V = 0.150\,\text{dm}^3n=213.00g mol−110.65g​;V=0.150dm3C1=10.65213.00×0.150mol dm−3C_1 = \dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}C1​=213.00×0.15010.65​mol dm−3For dilutions, we can use the formulaC1V1=C2V2C_1V_1 = C_2V_2C1​V1​=C2​V2​which relies on the number of moles in the concentrated stock solution being equal to the number of moles in the dilute, 1.0 mol dm3^33solution.Rearranging to find the volume of the stock solution required,V1V_1V1​,V1=C2×V2C1V_1 = \dfrac{C_2 \times  V_2}{C_1}V1​=C1​C2​×V2​​We are given thatC2=0.050mol dm−3C_2 = 0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}C2​=0.050mol dm−3andV2=1.0dm3.V_2 = 1.0\,\text{dm}^3.V2​=1.0dm3.Plugging these values in to the expression forV1,V_1,V1​,along with theC1C_1C1​found above, givesV1=0.050mol dm−3×1.0dm310.65213.00×0.150mol dm−3V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 1.0\,\text{dm}^3}{\frac{10.65}{213.00\times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}V1​=213.00×0.15010.65​mol dm−30.050mol dm−3×1.0dm3​V1=0.050×1.0×213.00×0.15010.65dm3V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\times 1.0\times 213.00\times 0.150}{10.65}\,\text{dm}^3V1​=10.650.050×1.0×213.00×0.150​dm3

list.title: Question 34
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Students must interpret the formula of the hydrated barium chloride.  Each unit of the hydrate contains 2 chlorine atoms.nCl=2×5.00mol=10.00moln_\ce{Cl} = 2 \times 5.00 \textrm{\ mol} = \answer{10.00 \textrm{\ mol}}nCl​=2×5.00mol=10.00mol​Similarly, 5.00 moles of the hydrate contain 20.00 moles of hydrogen atoms. The number of H atoms can be deduced by multiplying the amount by Avogadro's number,N=nNAN = nN_AN=nNA​:NH=6.02×1023mol−1×20.00mol=1.20×1025N_\ce{H} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1} \times 20.00\,\text{mol} = \answer{1.20\times 10^{25}}NH​=6.02×1023mol−1×20.00mol=1.20×1025​The molar mass ofBaClX2⋅2HX2O\ce{BaCl2.2H2O}BaClX2​⋅2HX2​Ocan be calculated by adding up the mass of each component atom:Mr=137.33+2(35.45)+2[2(1.01)+16.00]=244.27M_r = 137.33 + 2(35.45) + 2[2(1.01) + 16.00] = 244.27Mr​=137.33+2(35.45)+2[2(1.01)+16.00]=244.27The mass of5.00mol5.00\,\text{mol}5.00molofBaClX2⋅2HX2O\ce{BaCl2.2H2O}BaClX2​⋅2HX2​Ocan be calculated asm=nMm = n Mm=nM.m=5.00mol×244.27g mol−1=1221.35g=1.22×103gm = 5.00\,\text{mol} \times 244.27\,\text{g mol}^{-1} = 1221.35 \textrm{\ g} = \answer{1.22\times 10^3\,\text{g}}m=5.00mol×244.27g mol−1=1221.35g=1.22×103g​This question is categorized as hard since it includes many calculations with some hidden steps to figure out.Students must interpret the mole concepts and deduce the number of atoms by using Avogadro's number. In addition, the mass of the sample must be calculated with the relative formula mass determination.

list.title: Question 35
list.content: Water is added to200cm3200\,\text{cm}^3200cm3of a1.50×10−3mol dm−31.50\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}1.50×10−3mol dm−3HCl solution. The resulting solution has a volume300cm3300\,\text{cm}^3300cm3greater than the initial. Which statement is correct?A.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is6.00×10−4mol dm−3.6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.6.00×10−4mol dm−3.B.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is1.00×10−3mol dm−3.1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.1.00×10−3mol dm−3.C.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is6.00×10−4mol dm−3.6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.6.00×10−4mol dm−3.D.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is1.00×10−3mol dm−3.1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.1.00×10−3mol dm−3.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:This is a dilution problem. The key idea is that when solvent is added, the number of moles of solute stays the same while the total volume increases. First calculate the amount of solute in the original solution usingn=CV.n = CV.n=CV.n=1.50×10−3mol dm−3×0.200dm3=3.00×10−4moln = 1.50 \times 10^{-3} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \times 0.200 \textrm{\ dm}^3 = 3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}n=1.50×10−3mol dm−3×0.200dm3=3.00×10−4molAfter adding300,cm3300,\text{cm}^3300,cm3of water, the final volume is200+300=500cm3=0.500dm3200 + 300 = 500 \text{\ cm}^3 = 0.500 \text{\ dm}^3200+300=500cm3=0.500dm3.The concentration of the diluted solution is therefore[HCl]=3.00×10−4mol0.500dm3=6.00×10−4mol dm−3[\ce{HCl}] =  \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}}{0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = 6.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}[HCl]=0.500dm33.00×10−4mol​=6.00×10−4mol dm−3
